{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3134792,"name":null,"username":"shush","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/aeb1de/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-27T10:01:14.480Z","cooked":"

Hello! I saw in WPILib a package called “numbers”, which contains classes N0, N1, N2… up to N20. Each class only has one method, which returns the same int as in the class name.
What is the point? What could you use these classes for?

github.wpilib.org

edu.wpi.first.math.numbers (WPILib API 2023.2.1)

declaration: package: edu.wpi.first.math.numbers

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-01-27T10:01:14.480Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":136,"reads":229,"readers_count":228,"score":740.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":424821,"topic_slug":"math-numbers-package-why","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/java/edu/wpi/first/math/numbers/package-summary.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"edu.wpi.first.math.numbers (WPILib API 2023.2.1)","clicks":12}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51472,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming"},"post_url":"/t/math-numbers-package-why/424821/1","custom_user_title":"Programming","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3134793,"name":null,"username":"Starlight220","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starlight220/{size}/150872_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-27T10:18:12.964Z","cooked":"

They’re used for the generics in the linear algebra stuff. C++ templates directly on int values, but Java can’t do that.

Why not use Integer or Double?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-01-27T10:42:57.560Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":217,"readers_count":216,"score":73.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":424821,"topic_slug":"math-numbers-package-why","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":45763,"username":"Starlight220","name":null,"avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starlight220/{size}/150872_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51472,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming"},"post_url":"/t/math-numbers-package-why/424821/3","custom_user_title":"Programming","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3134802,"name":null,"username":"Starlight220","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starlight220/{size}/150872_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-27T11:28:02.800Z","cooked":"

Because those are types, and this is used as the numbers themselves.
For example, this C++ code for a 2-by-2 matrix:

Matrix<2, 2> matrix{0,0,0,0};

Everything here is checked at compile-time.
Java can’t do that. The best we can do is this:

Matrix<N2, N2> matrix = MatBuilder.fill(0,0,0,0);

It also means that size checks are done at runtime rather than compile time.

Oh, I get it. Thanks!

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-01-27T12:36:30.829Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":169,"readers_count":168,"score":48.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":424821,"topic_slug":"math-numbers-package-why","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":45763,"username":"Starlight220","name":null,"avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starlight220/{size}/150872_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51472,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming"},"post_url":"/t/math-numbers-package-why/424821/5","custom_user_title":"Programming","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3134861,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-27T14:53:25.764Z","cooked":"

One example of where they are used is the Matrix type. A four by four matrix has type Matrix<N4, N4>, a three by two matrix has type Matrix<N3, N2>. You can imagine that there could just be one Matrix type, with methods returning the dimensions, instead of separate types for each dimension of Matrix. The advantage of the WPILib approach, though, is that if you add two incompatible matrices, the code will fail at compile time rather than runtime.

But Integer(capital I) in java, is class not a type, so why wouldn’t that work?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-01-28T00:15:54.723Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":65,"readers_count":64,"score":18.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":424821,"topic_slug":"math-numbers-package-why","display_username":"Ibrahim Ahmad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":45763,"username":"Starlight220","name":null,"avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starlight220/{size}/150872_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53576,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CAN't Bus"},"post_url":"/t/math-numbers-package-why/424821/7","custom_user_title":"CAN't Bus","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3135175,"name":"alst","username":"alst","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/alst/{size}/11646_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-28T00:20:40.948Z","cooked":"

Integer is a type that can represent any integer. N2 is a type that can only “represent” 2.
